title: How to Clean up Broken Compact Fluorescent Light Bulbs

steps.headline: Do not vacuum up broken glass!
steps.description: This will vaporize and distribute all the mercury that was in the light bulb creating a much bigger problem.

steps.headline: Ventilate the room before you start cleanup.
steps.description: Make sure that the room is isolated (doors closed, heating/AC system turned off) from the rest of the structure. Open all windows and leave the room, do not track through breakage area. Let it air out for at least 15 minutes or longer.

steps.headline: Use rubber or latex gloves while cleaning up.
Use stiff paper or sticky tape to collect the larger pieces.
steps.description: NEVER use a broom or vacuum to sweep as this can disperse the particles or make them airborne. Place in a large resealable freezer bag.

steps.headline: Use the sticky side of duct tape to clean up all the small pieces.
Wipe the area down with a damp paper towel.
steps.description: Place used paper towels in freezer bag

steps.headline: Remove rubber gloves and place in freezer bag.
steps.description: Seal up the bag and bring it to a recycling or hazardous waist disposal facility.

steps.headline: Wash your hands and arms thoroughly.
Dispose of burned out CFLs properly.
steps.description: Even unbroken CFLs need to be disposed of properly. The following steps outline how this should be done.

steps.headline: Never throw burned out CFLs in ordinary waste.
steps.description: This is a sure way to contaminate the environment and in many areas it is against the law.

steps.headline: Collect burned out CFLs and take them to a recycling facility or hazardous waste disposal facility.
Find a disposal place.
steps.description: For a disposal center near you in the USA, check the US EPA web site on Mercury-Containing Light Bulb Recycling.

text: Do not vacuum up broken glass! This will vaporize and distribute all the mercury that was in the light bulb creating a much bigger problem. Ventilate the room before you start cleanup. Make sure that the room is isolated (doors closed, heating/AC system turned off) from the rest of the structure. Open all windows and leave the room, do not track through breakage area. Let it air out for at least 15 minutes or longer. Use rubber or latex gloves while cleaning up.  Use stiff paper or sticky tape to collect the larger pieces. NEVER use a broom or vacuum to sweep as this can disperse the particles or make them airborne. Place in a large resealable freezer bag. Use the sticky side of duct tape to clean up all the small pieces. Place in freezer bag. Wipe the area down with a damp paper towel. Place used paper towels in freezer bag Remove rubber gloves and place in freezer bag. Seal up the bag and bring it to a recycling or hazardous waist disposal facility. Wash your hands and arms thoroughly.  Dispose of burned out CFLs properly. Even unbroken CFLs need to be disposed of properly. The following steps outline how this should be done. Never throw burned out CFLs in ordinary waste. This is a sure way to contaminate the environment and in many areas it is against the law. Collect burned out CFLs and take them to a recycling facility or hazardous waste disposal facility.  Find a disposal place.
